loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is 33 years old and has two children. She is married and both her children are in school.

Evelyn is in the agricultural business raising pigs in the Philippines. Evelyn requested a PHP 19,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Evelyn has been raising pigs for three years now and has borrowed five times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Evelyn would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios works hard to support her family. She is married and has a food vending business in the Philippines.

Remedios requested a PHP 22,000 loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business. She has been in this business for 30 years.

In the future, Remedios would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business.

loans.name: Meck

texts.en:
30 year old Meck is a garment factory worker. Her husband is a construction worker, and their combined income is $7 per day. They have 3 children; two are studying and the third is in construction with his father. 

Every month, Meck has to spend $24 on food and $20 on other family expenses.  She would like to request a loan of $500 to buy a motorbike for her husband, so he can start a taxi business when he is not working construction. He knows how to repair motorbikes, so Meck wants to set up a small motorbike repair shop for him at home when they have enough resources to do it.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa, owner of Native Hand by Hand and Silver Fashions, comes from a family of artisans in Ecuador. Alongside her siblings and parents, she would spend 12 hours a day creating beautiful handmade clothing and jewelry and selling it at markets.  When she moved to San Francisco in 1985, she had to put her artisanal talents temporarily on hold as she cleaned homes to make a living. However, after she gave birth to her daughter in 1993, her commitment to family and her love for handicrafts led her to resume selling artisanal crafts.   

“When I gave birth to my daughter, I realized how important it was to be able to spend more time with her. I needed a job that would allow me to take care of my child.” 

As she had once done in Ecuador, Rosa began selling her clothing and jewelry in the streets of the Mission, a San Francisco neighborhood—but this time she is able to earn a living through the arts while working significantly fewer hours than she did as a child or in her career cleaning houses. 

“I work extremely hard. Owning my own shop gives me the freedom to create my own schedule and spend time with family, as well”, Rosa noted. 

Word of Rosa’s beautiful jewelry has spread over the years and her business has grown so much that she was able to open up a storefront right in the Mission, named Native Hand by Hand and Silver Fashions. But in 2009, when she wanted a loan in order to expand her business, she was considered “unbankable” by major banks because she did not have any credit history. After a friend referred her to Opportunity Fund, she used a microloan to buy more inventory. She was able to pay back her loan and increase her credit score to 727. Now she has established her credit history and become more integrated into the U.S. financial system.

Rosa wants to expand her business even more in order to pay for her daughter’s college and she needs a loan for $1,500 to purchase additional inventory for her store.  “I am so proud of my daughter for having graduated from high school this spring,” she said. But along with this joy comes the necessity of providing for further education. This second microloan will aid her in supporting her family and following her dreams by continuing to grow her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory for her store, such as jewelry and handmade crafts.

loans.name: Larch

texts.en:
Larch is a housewife. Her husband used to be a teacher but now he is retired. They have 3 children; one is studying, and the other two are working in a factory with an income of $3 per day each. 

Larch depends on her children to pay the family expenses – about $100 per month – because she does not have an income. She would like to request a loan of $300 for her third child’s school fees. She will try to send her child to school until he finishes university. All her children will help to repay the loan. She wants to sell gruel in front of her house when she has enough money.

loans.use: to pay her child's school fees

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
Beatriz is married with seven children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Beatriz is 46 years old and has 1 child who is in school.

Beatriz has an "abaca" making business in the Philippines. Beatriz requested a PHP 25,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy materials for her "abaca"-making business.

Beatriz has been in this business for seven years. In the future, Beatriz would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy materials for her "abaca" (natural fiber) making business.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is 42 years of age and is married to a farmer. They have two children. She has been running a livestock business for five years and earns PHP5,000 every four months. Grace is requesting a loan of PHP12,000 to purchase additional hogs to raise and hogfeed supplement. She raises hogs to gain income because she wants her two children to finish their education someday. She hopes to increase her business income.

loans.use: to purchase additional hogs to raise and pigfeed supplement

loans.name: Feliciana

texts.en:
Feliciana is 37 years old and has eight children. Feliciana is married and has four children who are in school.

Feliciana is in the agricultural business raising livestock in the Philippines. Feliciana requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more livestock to sell.

Feliciana has been raising livestock for three years now and has borrowed three times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Feliciana would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more livestock to sell.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
36 year old Sam is a garment factory worker with an income of $3 per day. She is a single mother with 4 children, three of whom are students. The fourth – a daughter – is a potter. She makes pottery to sell at home and she can make $1 per day. 

Every month Sam has to spend $60 on food and $20 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $300 to buy materials for her daughter to make more pottery to sell, so that she can make more income from it and help Sam support her other children through to the end of their high school studies. In the future, Sam wants to start a tailoring shop at home because she wants to stay there to take care of her children.

loans.use: To buy materials for her daughter's pottery business

loans.name: Sarum

texts.en: Sarum, 38 years old, is a grocery seller. Her husband is a worker and their income is $6 per day. She has three children: one is studying and the other two are working in a factory. Every month, she has to spend $100 on food, $10 on school fees and $13 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $800 to buy groceries to sell from home. Previously, she sold fruit in Phnom Penh City, but she wants to have a career at home to take care of her children. Therefore, she decided to take a loan to start this career and she expects to earn more income.

loans.use: To buy groceries to sell

loans.name: Sarum

texts.en: Sarum, 59 years old, is a vegetable seller earning $10 per day. Her husband is retired. She has 6 children: three are studying and the other three are working and earn about $11 per day. Every month she has to spend $165 on food, $30 on school fees, $10 on electricity and $40 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $500 to buy a motorbike for her son to travel to work. She has a plan to get a tailoring shop for her daughter at home when she has enough money.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her son to travel to work

loans.name: Meng

texts.en:
Mr. Meng, 41, is a poor man who has worked hard and operated his farming business for over four years. On average, Mr. Meng is able to earn around $3.50 each day for their daily expenses. As a part-time job, he often goes to buy some firewood to burn in order to produce charcoal and his wife normally takes the charcoal from him, as well as buying some from other charcoal producers, to sell in their community in Siem Reap Province. 

The couple tries to help each other to support their four children, all of whom are still living under their roof and depend on their daily income. Mr. Meng will be using his loan for purchasing additional firewood to burn into charcoal that he can sell and he will get more profit from his charcoal-selling business. For the remainder of the fund, he intends to plant potatoes and purchase fertilizers.

loans.use: to purchase additional firewood to burn into charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Cheu

texts.en:
Mr. Cheu is a 27-year-old married father who lives in Siem Reap Province. He owns a medium-sized phone shop next to his village where he sells mobile phones. He also buys new phones and used phones at reasonable prices from people in the village and then sells them to make a profit. 

He started his business early in 2006, and he earns  about $4.50 per day that mainly serves to meet his family’s daily expenses. His wife sells fixed goods next to Mr. Cheu’s shop and also grows a few potato plants to generate some income. 

Mr. Cheu requests a loan to buy more mobile phones for sale, and  he will use an remainder of the loan to grow potato seed. Mr. Cheu is blessed with three children who are attending local schools.

loans.use: to buy more mobile phones for sale and to grow potato seed.

loans.name: Kiem

texts.en:
Mrs. Kiem, 42, is homemaker. She stays at home to care for her four children and tends to her daily routine as well. Mrs. Kiem’s husband provides for the family’s expenses with his income as a motor taxi driver in and around Siem Reap Province. Besides this, he was hired by his neighbors to guard their land for extra income. 

Mrs. Kiem is applying for loan to buy some ducks and chickens to raise for sale and also to ordain her son as a Buddhist monk.  Mrs. Kiem is photographed with her husband in front of their house.

loans.use: to buy some ducks and chickens to raise for sale and also to ordain her son as a Buddhist monk.

loans.name: Rosel

texts.en:
Rosel is married with two children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Rosel is 53 years old and has two children who are in school.

Rosel has a business in the Philippines buying and selling bananas. Rosel requested a PHP 30,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy additional bananas to sell.

Rosel has been in this business for 30 years. In the future, Rosel would like to save enough money to buy farm land and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy additional bananas to sell.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael is 39 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with 2 children. 
Michael provides motorela, or habal-habal services, while his wife manages their retail store selling snacks. He has had this business for 5 years. He requested a loan of PHP 16,000 to buy tools & to pay for utilities needed to provide his service.
Michael has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Michael hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy tools & pay for utilities needed to provide his service

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is 54 years old, married and has 8 adult children. She has a retail shop where she sells a variety of products. She has been doing this work for 15 years and earns approximately Php 5,000 monthly.

Veronica is requesting a loan of Php 13,000 to purchase soft drinks, bread, noodles and canned goods to sell.

In the future, Veronica hopes that she will earn more income to meet the daily needs of her family.

loans.use: to purchase soft drinks, bread, noodles and canned goods to sell

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma has a shop that sells bread, biscuits and snacks. She has had this business for 6 years. Emma is 39 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with four children. 

Emma has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. She requested a loan of 14,000 Philippine pesos to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages. In the future, Emma hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy feed for her pigs to be sold.

loans.name: Cheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Cheap has been operating a crop-planting business since 2000 in the Prey Chor district of Kompong Cham Province. She is a local cultivator and is earning an average of $2 a day. Other income comes from her husband’s occupation as a domestic construction worker. He makes around $3 a day to participate with Mrs. Cheap in covering the family’s daily needs. 

Presently, they always hire a motor taxi when they need to go anywhere as they don’t have their own vehicle. So Mrs. Cheap would like to take out a loan in order to purchase a used motorbike for their traveling needs; it can save money spent on motor taxi service. She hopes to use the remainder of the cash to pay for plowing and harvest costs.

loans.use: to purchase a used motorbike for their traveling needs and pay for plowing and harvest costs.

loans.name: Marieta

texts.en:
Marieta has a vegetable shop that sells a variety of vegetables. She has had this business for six years. Marieta is 38 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is single. 

Marieta has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. She requested a loan of 14,000 Philippine pesos to buy fertilizers for her vegetable plants. In the future, Marieta hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizes for her vegetable plants.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fish to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy additional vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Tenizbek

texts.en:
Tenizbek is a farmer who lives in Kichi-Kemin village. He is 64, married and has three children. He graduated from Automotive College and worked as a mechanic at the local station. In order to find an additional means of subsistence for his family, Tenizbek decided to start his own business in cattle breeding. Using his initial capital of 5,000 soms (KGS), he bought only one calf. His start as an entrepreneur was successful due to strong efforts, and today he has two milk cows, one horse and twenty sheep. Also, for 20 years, Tenizbek has been engaged in his favorite activity – bee farming . At present, he has 40 bee families and earns about 10,000 KGS monthly from selling the products of beekeeping. 

Tenizbek has applied for a loan of 75,000 KGS to buy more milk cows that will allow him to increase his milk sales and increase his number of customers. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target an especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Esterlita

texts.en:
Esterlita is 58 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 4 children. 
Esterlita has a shop that sells furniture of different designs. She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan of PHP 7,000 to buy raw materials needed for furniture making.
Esterlita has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Esterlita hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw materials needed for furniture making

loans.name: Tserenhuu

texts.en: Tserenhuu is 51 years old and lives with her husband and two children in a ger, a Mongolian yurt, in the Narantuul area of Ulaanbaatar city. Her two children, aged 10 and 13, go to a secondary school. She manages a men's clothing business with the help of her husband. She started her business in 1999. They purchase stock 1-2 times a month. Now their working capital exceeds 1,300,000 MNT and she earns 65,000 MNT monthly. She is a hardworking woman who says, "I want to have my land certificate soon." She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more clothing for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing

loans.name: Precilda

texts.en:
Precilda says that "through patience and determination, life becomes easier." She is a positive thinker and has a strong faith in God.

Precilda is 53 years old and is married with 4 adult children. She has had a food selling business for 5 years and earns about Php 4,000 monthly.

Precilda sells different kinds of fruits and vegetables to locals. 
Precilda is requesting a loan of Php 7,000 to buy more banana, squash, eggplant, tomato and cabbage to sell.

In the future, Precilda is looking ahead and hopes that she can expand her business to sustain the needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy more banana, squash, eggplant, tomato and cabbage to sell

loans.name: Pok

texts.en:
Cultivating rice is part of 38-year-old Mrs. Pok's daily routine in Prey Chor district. Rice is an essential product, vital to Cambodian people. She learned to grow it from her grandmother and she is very widely known in this sector since before she was married. Her husband, Mr. So, assists her with the farm work as well as providing horse cart services in the marketplace. They have four children, one of whom is employed as a garment factory worker and has a formal salary to contribute to the family's financial expenses. 

Mrs. Pok will be using her loan to help her husband to buy a new horse in place of the old horse which is becoming older and older and cannot support her husband in transportation services well.  She will use any remainder of the loan to buy insecticides, fertilizers, and seeds for planting. Mrs. Pok, her husband, and their two young kids appear in the photograph together.

loans.use: to buy a new horse to replace their old horse and also buy insecticides, fertilizers, and seeds for planting.

loans.name: Long

texts.en:
The woman in the photograph is Mrs. Long, age 30. She is a rice cultivator who currently lives in the Prey Chor district of Kompong Cham. To earn a daily income, she plants rice crops and a few vegetables on her own farmland. She typically makes an income of approximately $3 each day. Her husband works alongside her in the farm fields. 

Mrs. Long has given birth to three children; all of them are single and under her care. Mrs. Long is applying for a loan to purchase a plowing machine to plow her farmland.

loans.use: to purchase a plowing machine to plow her farmland.

loans.name: Gantumur

texts.en: Gantumur is 48-year-old, divorced woman who lives with her two daughters who attend college. They live in an apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She manages a shoe trading business at a rented stall at Narantuul, one of the biggest markets in Mongolia. She started her business in 2008 and since then has been able to stabilize her business. Now her working capital exceeds 2,000,000 MNT. She earns 60,000 MNT monthly and purchases stock 1-2 times a month. She is a polite woman who says, "I want to expand my business." She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more shoes from Erlian.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes from Erlian

loans.name: Yanjinlham

texts.en: Yanjinlham is 41 years old and lives with her husband and three children in a ger, a Mongolian yurt, in Ulaanbaatar city. Her older daughter goes to secondary school while the younger two are in kindergarten. She manages a meat trading business with the help of her husband at a rented stall at Narantuul market. She has been operating her business for 10 years and has gained much experience. She is a hardworking lady who says, "I want to expand my business in the future." She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase livestock for her business.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Munhtsetseg

texts.en: Munhtsetseg is 37 years old and lives with her husband and three children in a ger, a Mongolian yurt, in the Huvsgul province of Mongolia. Her older two children attend secondary school while the younger one is in kindergarten. Her husband is a driver who operates his own transportation business. She manages a tailoring business at her workshop. She started her business in 2006 with a workshop built near her home. She receives quite a lot orders from her customers and sells her products while visiting homes. She is a hardworking lady who wants to have her own shop and to employ more workers. She says, "I would like to do construction and decoration work at my work place and to have a new sewing machine for my business." She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase a new sewing machine and to repair her work place.

loans.use: To purchase a new sewing machine

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her crop.

loans.name: Uranbileg

texts.en: Uranbileg is 40 years old and lives with her husband and two children in a house in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. Her younger son goes to secondary school while her husband works as a carpenter. She manages a wooden product making business with family help. She started her business in 2002 and has gained much experience. During summer her older son, her husband and Uranbileg work as interior decorators and during winter they make their wooden products such as chairs, tables and hangers. With their earnings they are planning to build a winter house for family use. They are all very diligent and hardworking people who are going to continue and expand their business. She says, "We are planning to complete construction work of our winter house in August." She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase wood for her business.

loans.use: To purchase wood

loans.name: Neang

texts.en: The woman in the photograph, Mrs. Neang, age 56, lives in the province of Kompong Cham, which is the best territory for farming. Mrs. Neang is a married woman who is devoted to her six children.  Three of her children are married and live in the other house. The three remaining are single, two of whom work on the farm, while the third attends school and depends on her care. Mrs. Neang owns a big farm that she inherited from her grandmother. She uses her farmland to grow a various crops. Her husband also assists her in same business. Presently, Mrs. Neang has another farm that she owns, but does not plant crops on it yet. Mrs. Neang hopes to use her Kiva loan to purchase peanut seed to plant on the second farm.  The loan will also be used to buy more fish-feed for the large pond next her house.

loans.use: to purchase peanut seed as well as buy more fish-feed

loans.name: Kanatbek

texts.en:
Kanabek is married and has three children. He was born in Kashkelen village in a large family and spent most of his time helping his parents in the household, pasturing cattle in the mountainous areas with native grasses, and helping his mother milk the cows. 

After graduating from secondary school, Kanatbek devoted his life to breeding animals and land cultivation. Gaining wide experience in this activity, the start-up of his own business was successful. With the initial capital of 2.000 KGS, which was spent purchasing seeds of clover and wheat, he managed to earn about 3,000 KGS each month. 
As farming is the major means of subsistence for Kanatbek’s family, he spends a lot of time improving his farm. Being a persistent and hard-working man, he has developed his farm and presently has one milk cow, calves and 2.4 hectares of irrigated land. 

Kanatbek plans to use this loan of 30,000 KGS to broaden his livestock business. In the future, he dreams of building a big house for his children and grandchildren. 

About Bai-Tushum and Partners:

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable members of the population. It is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, it contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
This is Lorena, 43, a resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Arnulfo, a baker, and is the mother of their 4 children. She, together with her husband and children, manages the household while operating the business. She is continually working hard to provide income for their everyday expenses and her children’s studies. This is a dream for most poor Filipino parents, like Lorena, as she herself has been an undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave their children.

Lorena operates a variety store. In the Philippines a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages, piecemeal to locals. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Lorena earns income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Aside from the variety store, she has a bakeshop where she sells different kinds of bread and pastries. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 605 in sales every day.

To help her to continue business operations, she is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She’ll also invest a portion of the loan to buy ingredients to be used in the bakeshop. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Lorena hopes to be able to expand soon. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for groceries for her store.

loans.name: Jovelyn

texts.en:
Jovelyn is 23 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 2 children. 
Jovelyn has a shop that sells fish like sardines & milk fish. She has had this business for 5 years. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy fish to sell.
Jovelyn has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Jovelyn hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy fish to sell

loans.name: Rita Marie

texts.en:
Rita Marie is 22 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 1 child. 
Rita Marie has a food shop that sells viands like chicken & pork adobo (pork seasoned with soy, garlic, vinegar and spices). She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy raw ingredients needed for cooking dishes.
Rita Marie has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Rita Marie hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients needed for cooking dishes

loans.name: Joann

texts.en:
Joann is 30 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 2 children. 
Joann has a shop that sells vegetables like tomatoes & string beans. She has had this business for 8 years. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy additional vegetables.
Joann has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Joann hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy additional vegetables

loans.name: Mildred

texts.en:
Mildred is 68 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 5 children. 
Mildred has a shop that sells candies, snacks & canned goods. She has had this business for 1 year. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, beverages & snacks.
Mildred has been a new member of HSPFI. In the future, Mildred hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, beverages & snacks

loans.name: Alberto

texts.en:
Alberto is 59 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is a widower with 1 child. 
Alberto has a shop that sells food supplements like Spirulina. He has had this business for 5 years. He requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy additional Spirulina supplements.
Alberto is a  new member of HSPFI. In the future, Alberto hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy additional Spirulina supplements

loans.name: Maria Cecelia

texts.en:
Maria Cecelia is 52 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 5 children. 
Maria Cecelia has a retail shop that sells used clothing or ukay-ukay. She has had this business for 3 years. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy stock of used clothing.
Maria Cecelia is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Maria Cecelia hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy stocks of used clothing

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena, 41 and single is a resident of Quezon City, Philippines. She manages her own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

Rowena operates a food stall. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most families only eat home-cooked meals during evenings where all the family members are at home to partake of the meal. This is not only a usual family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend cooking gas and food for one to two persons when buying cooked rice and viands costs less than raw food. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of  PHP 600 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operation of her business, Rowena is requesting a PHP 8,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Rowena dreams of being able to give all of her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for ingredients and products she needs for her business.

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en: Cristina is 31 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with one child. Cristina has a retail shop that sells beverages, candies and biscuits. She has had this business for five years. She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, beverages and breads. Cristina is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, beverages and breads

loans.name: Ny

texts.en:
Ny, 59, is a resident of Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Alvaro and the mother of three children who all have their own family. She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Ny sells cassava cake snacks to the local neighborhood. She buys grated cassava in the market in the morning together with other raw products that she needs like margarine, sugar and coconut. She cooks and prepares the snacks and sells them in the afternoon in her local neighborhood. She earns a minimum of PHP 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 8,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy raw products and ingredients that she uses in her business. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. 

Ny hopes to be able to expand her business soon. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God which she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw ingredients and products that she uses in her business.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en: Jocelyn is 37 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with four children. Jocelyn has a retail shop that sells marinated chicken and home-made mango puree. She has had this business for one year. She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy raw ingredients for the marinated chicken which she sells. Jocelyn is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for the marinated chicken which she sells

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is 46 years old with eight adult children. She has a manufacturing business where she makes and sells a variety of furniture like sala (patio) sets, dining tables and chairs. Susan is a beginner in this business because she has been doing it for only one year. She earns PHP 4,000 per month doing this type of work.

Susan is asking for a loan of PHP 13,000 to buy wood, paintbrushes and varnish to make more furniture to sell.

In the future, Susan hopes that her business will expand to provide for her family's needs.

loans.use: to buy wood, paintbrushes and varnish to make more furniture

loans.name: Lizel

texts.en: Lizel is 23 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with one child.  Lizel has a retail shop that sells noodles, canned goods and snacks. She has had this business for one year. She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy beverages and snacks to sell. Lizel is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy beverages and snacks to sell

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine, 40, is a resident of Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Leonido, a security guard, and is the mother of one child. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Josephine operates a tailoring business. She mainly offers curtains, bed sheets, blankets, and other home trappings which she sells to her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her to continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 8,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and newspapers for patterns for use in her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Josephine hopes to be able to expand her business soon. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God which she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw materials like fabric, thread and newspapers for patterns for use in her business.

loans.name: Riza

texts.en: Riza is 34 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with nine children. Riza has a food shop that sells viands like chicken adobo (marinated) and afritada (stew). She has had this business for one year. She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy raw ingredients needed for making dishes to sell. Riza is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients needed for making dishes to sell

loans.name: Minerva

texts.en:
Minerva, 51, is a resident of Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Cionito and the mother of two children. She, together with her husband and children, manage their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Minerva operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Minerva earns income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling each item. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 8,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Minerva hopes to be able to expand her business soon, just as she fervently hopes that her children will be able to graduate one day, and finish their studies. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God which she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her business's product inventory.

loans.name: Maria Nita

texts.en: Maria Nita is 55 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. Maria Nita has a retail shop that sells candies, snacks and beverages. She has had this business for six years. She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, beverages and detergents. Maria Nita is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, beverages and detergents

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy varnish, nails and soft wood to make more furniture to sell

loans.name: Melchedick

texts.en:
Melchedick is 42 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with six children. Melchedick provides motorela or habal-habal (motorcycle taxi) services. He has had this business for 11 years. He has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy tools and to pay for the utilities needed for the service.

Melchedick is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, he hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy tools and to pay for the utilities needed for the service

loans.name: Vouen

texts.en: Vouen, aged 45, is a worker. She is a single mother with three children, one of whom is studying while the other two work in a factory. This family can earn income of $10 per day. Every month, she has to spend $65 on food, $4 on electricity, and $10 on school fees. She would like to request a loan of $1000 to buy a motorbike for her son to travel to work. She plans to get a small store in the market so her daughter can sell groceries instead of working in the factory: after her son finishes high school she wants him to study motorbike repair. She expects their daily income can support her children and achieve her plans.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her son to travel to work

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah, 62, is a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Wilfredo, a driver, and the mother of four children. By the grace of God, Sarah has managed to support her older children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to send her youngest to college. This is a dream for most poor Filipino parents, like Sarah, as she herself has been an undergraduate, and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Sarah operates a food stall. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most families only eat home-cooked meals during evenings when all of the family members are at home to partake of the meal. This is not only the usual family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend cooking gas and food for one to two persons when buying cooked rice and viands costs less than raw food. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue her business operations, Sarah is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Sarah dreams of being able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and to also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God which she studies.

 * All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings needed for her business.

loans.name: Khut

texts.en: Mrs. Khut, 30, and her husband are construction workers in and around Siem Ream Province. Her husband is good at building stone and wooden houses. He also has a few domestic laborers to assist him. Recently, Mrs. Khut's husband has been very busy with many clients who hired him to build their houses, but he needs material for construction.  Mrs. Khut has requested a loan as capital to buy extra construction materials for their business. In future Mrs. Khut wants to buy a new motorbike to ride to work and also build a new house for her family.

loans.use: to buy extra construction materials.

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en: Rosalie is 28 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with four children. Rosalie has a retail shop that sells bananas and viands (food) like pancit bihon (a rice noodle dish). She has had this business for one year. She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy bananas and additional raw ingredients for food preparation. Rosalie is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy bananas and additional raw ingredients for food preparation

loans.name: Gretchen

texts.en: Gretchen is 22 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is single with one child. Gretchen has a retail shop that sells canned goods, candies and breads. She has had this business for two years. She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods and beverages. Gretchen is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods and beverages to sell

loans.name: Oun

texts.en: Oun, aged 40, works in the casino. Her husband is a chief construction worker; their income is $10 per day. They have two children, one of whom is studying and the other works in the casino with his mother; he can earn income of $3 per day. Oun has to spend around $100 per month for all her family's expenses. She would like to request a loan of $1000 to buy a plot of land for planting Khmer potatoes. She also wants to support her youngest child's studies until she finishes university and gets a good job.

loans.use: To buy a plot of land for planting Khmer potatoes

loans.name: Julita

texts.en:
Julita, 37, is a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Rogito, a salesman, and is the mother of four children. By the grace of God, Julita has managed to support her older children's schooling up to high school level. At this time, she is working hard to send her children to school. This is a dream for most poor Filipino parents like Julita as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Julita operates a bicycle parts business. What she basically does is buy general merchandise from wholesalers and sell them per item with a little profit. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options they are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 1000 in sales every day.

To help her continue her business operations, she is requesting a PHP 50,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Julita dreams of being able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and to also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God which she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her inventory in her bicycle parts business.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria, aged 40, is married with three school-aged children. She has a retail shop where she sells different products that she can offer to the community. Maria has had this business for 18 years and she earns approximately PHP 3,000 monthly.

Maria is requesting a loan of PHP 7,000 to purchase a variety of products so that she can offer more products to the community to acquire more customers, thus increasing her income. She wants to buy canned goods, noodles and other daily basic necessities to sell to the community.

In the future, Maria hopes that her business will expand to sustain her family's daily needs and also to finance her children's schooling.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, noodles and other daily basic necessities to sell

loans.name: Sarouet

texts.en:
Sarouet, 38, is a grocery seller. Her husband is a car driver and sometime he does motorbike taxi driving to get more income. Their income is $10 per day. They have five children, three are studying and one works in a cosmetic shop earning $5 per day. Every month, Sarouet has to spend $75 on food, $15 on school fees, and $10 on transportation. 

Sarouet would like to request a loan of $1000 to buy a new motorbike for her husband's motorbike taxi service because the current motorbike is old and needs a lot of repairs. In the future she wants to extend her shop to sell more grocery goods so that she can earn more income to support the rest of her children who are studying so they can finish university.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike for her husband's taxi service

loans.name: Sinoun

texts.en:
Sinoun, 27 year old, is a grocery seller.  Her husband is a motor taxi driver and their income is $9 per day.  They have one child and he is one year old. 

Every month, she has to spend $75 on food and $15 on transportation.  She would like to request a loan of $600 to buy a new motorbike for her husband for his motor taxi driving because the current motorbike is too old and needs a lot of repairs.  She wants to extend her grocery shop to sell more goods.  She also plans to buy a house because right now she stays with her mother, so she wants to get her own house for her family.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband's motorbike transport business.

loans.name: Sajida's Group

texts.en:
Sajida is 35 years old, married, and has five children. Her husband has a soft drink corner in the nearby market where he serves his customers with chilled drinks and generates income for the family. 

Sajida is a very cooperative lady. She supports her husband financially by sewing clothes for her neighborhood clients. Her sewing skill earns her a good amount of income every month, which she utilizes to manage her household expenses. 

Her children are young and study in different classes by attending a local school. 

Sajida has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who wants to invest it in his soft drink business. With the loan, he will buy soft drinks like Coca Cola, Pepsi, Sprite etc. to be able to sell to his customers and generate more income. 

Sajida is very hopeful that after the loan investment, his business will grow in a positive direction. 

Note: "In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Sajida".

loans.use: To buy soft drinks

loans.name: Luna

texts.en:
As a married parent of 8 children, Luna works hard to support her family.

She has a shells crafting business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from food vending.  Luna is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to buy materials like nylon for her shells crafting business.

Luna has been sustaining her business activities through her past 5 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy materials like nylon for her shells crafting business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John has been running a spare parts shop for the last six years in C.B.D Nairobi capital city.  He earns an income of KES. 60,000 per month.  He is married to Grace and they have two school aged children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by a Kadet staff and he is applying for his second loan after paying back his previous loan in good time.  John plans to use the entire loan amount to buy car spare parts and motorbike spare parts.

The anticipated profits will be used to add more stock and in the future he plans to grow his business and own a big spare parts shop.

loans.use: To buy car spare parts worth KES 40,000 and motor bike spare parts worth KES 40,000

loans.name: Ma. Fe

texts.en:
Ma. Fe works hard to support her family. Ma. Fe is married and has a sari-sari store in the Philippines.

Ma. Fe requested a loan of PHP 12,000 through NWTF to buy items like coffee and groceries to sell in her sari-sari store.

Ma. Fe has been in this business for 3 years.

In future, Ma. Fe would like to build and expand her business to support the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to buy bread, noodles and snack food to sell in her sari-sari store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita is 58 years old, married, and has five children. Rita works hard to provide for her family. She runs a variety store in the Philippines. She has requested a 20,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more inventory to sell and computer supplies.

Rita has borrowed and paid eleven loans from NWTF prior to this loan. She has been running the variety store for 40 years. She also earns an income from an internet cafe.

Rita aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more inventory to sell and computer supplies

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida is 35 years old and married with 2 children. Leonida works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 15,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more items to sell.

Leonida has borrowed and paid 6 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 4 years and also earns an income from used clothing. Leonida aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more items for her store

loans.name: Abanyamutima Group

texts.fr: Jacqueline  est une commerçante, elle est le membre du groupe Abanyamutima. Elle est âgée de 29 ans, elle est mariée, est elle est né au Rwanda.  Elle a 3 enfants  entre 4ans et 9 ans, tous 3 vont à l’école, son niveau d’éducation est 6 ans des études  secondaire. C’est son premier cycle de prêt avec ACB.  Elle va acheter  des chemises, robes, pantalons, sous vêtements, tricots, et les vêtements des enfants. Sa stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire est  l’amélioration des connaissances dans le service commercial pour bien gérer son business. Dans l’avenir elle voudrait  devenir une grande commerçante dans la région, construire sa propre maison, pour sa famille elle voudrait éduquer ses enfants jusqu’au niveau de l’université.
texts.en: Jacqueline is a merchant and a member of the Abanyamutima group. She is 29 years old, married, and was born in Rwanda. She has three children between the ages of 4 and 9, all of whom attend school, and her own education extended up through 6 years of secondary school. This is her first loan cycle with ACB. She is going to buy shirts, dresses, pants, undergarments, sweaters, and children's clothing. Her strategy to increase her sales volume is to improve her commercial and service relationships to better manage her business. In the future she would like to become a major merchant in her area, build her own house and, for her family, educate her children through the university level.

loans.use: To buy shirts, dresses, pants, undergarments, sweaters, and children's clothing.

loans.name: Moueng

texts.en:
Moueng, 68 year old, is a house wife.  She lives with one child.  He is married with 2 children.  He is a worker who earns $2.50 per day for his income. 

Every month she has to spend around $70 for all the expenses for the family, and her child is responsible for that.  She would like to request a loan of $500 to repair her house, build a toilet and rest room.  The payment will be responsible by her children.

loans.use: To repair her house

loans.name: Bella

texts.en:
Bella is 43 years old and has one child. Bella earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. She is borrowing 12,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs. She has been raising pigs for 15 years and also earns additional income from food vending.

Bella is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she could afford to send her child to college.

loans.use: to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en:
Sokha, 44 year old, is a cake seller.  Her husband is a pig feeder and their income is $6 per day.  They have 4 children and all of them are studying in school. 

Every month, she has to spend $80 on food, $40 on school fees and $5 on electricity.  She would like to request a loan for $500 to buy more pigs to raise.  She hopes to make more income from her career by extending her farm to make it a bit bigger than now and to get more animals to raise, not just pigs, because she needs to support all of her four children to study until they finish university.

loans.use: To buy more pigs to raise

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha is 56 years old and married with 4 children. She works very hard to provide for them.

Editha runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a 25,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy items like shampoo, groceries, etc. for her sari-sari store. Editha has been in this business for 10 years and sells a variety of items such as sugar, soap, curls, bread, etc.. 

In the future Editha would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena is a widow with 2 children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Elena is 48 years old and has 1 child who is in school.

Elena has a business buying and selling fish and spices in the Philippines. Elena requested a 13,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to buy additional fish and spices to sell. She has been in this business for 19 years. 

In the future, Elena would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her child to college.

loans.use: to buy additional fish and spices to sell

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is 35 years old and married with 3 children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a 27,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock like sardines, spices, eggs, etc. for her sari-sari store. Evelyn has borrowed and paid 14 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 5 years and also earns an income from house rentals.

Evelyn aspires to build and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell

loans.name: Sany

texts.en:
Sany, 42 year old, is selling food from her home.  She is a single mother and has one child who is 6 years old. 

Every month, she has to spend around $50 on food and other expenses.  Her income is about $10 per day.  She would like to request a loan of $1,200 to buy meat and other things for making food and soup to sell.  She hopes to make more income so that she can expand her business and be able to send her child to study and to at least finish high school.

loans.use: To buy meat and other things for making food and soup to sell

loans.name: Abida's Group

texts.en:
Abida is a caring lady, carrying out her responsibilities as a housewife by staying at home. 

She is also a very caring mother, raising her children with great care. She has enrolled all three of her children in school so they can get an education and make their future bright. 

Her husband is a welder as well as a spare parts dealer. His shop is located in the market.

Abida has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who will use the loan to purchase a new welding machine and some spare parts for his business. 

He has been operating his business for the past 17 years and Abida is hopeful that an investment will bring more profits to her husband and improve her family's lifestyle. 

Note: in the photo, the lady raising her hand is Abida.

loans.use: To buy a new welding machine & spare parts

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a 32-year-old. has three children, two of whom are in school,she has been in this business of selling fish for two years she request a loan from BRAC south sudan to expand her business.she will use her profits to pay the school fees of her children.

loans.use: She want more income to able her purchase more fish for sale.

loans.name: Marita

texts.en:
Marita, from the village of Naguillan, Isabela, is a 54-year-old married mother of four grown children. Her main income derives from making and selling a variety of fashion accessories, a business she has operated for over 10 years, earning her a monthly income of approximately PHP 5,000.

Hoping to increase her income to give more support to her family needs, Marita is requesting a loan of Php 11,000 to buy additional materials to make more fashion jewelry to sell. In the future, she dreams of having her own stall to sell more kinds of accessories.

loans.use: to buy additional materials to make more fashion accessories to sell.

loans.name: Joice

texts.en: Joice is 28 years old, married to a farmer,she has five children, four of whom are in school.she has been in this business of making local alcohol for three years she request a loan  through BRAC south sudan to expand her business. With the extra profits raised from her loan, Joice hopes to be able to pay her children school fees.

loans.use: to able her purchase more local alcohol for sale

loans.name: C4829Tuzamurane Group

texts.en:
Jeanne is 27 years old and is married with one child who is one year old. She owns a restaurant selling food and drinks.  Jeanne is the president of this group, called "TUZAMURANE" in local language. 

She is the first person on the left side. She has been in this business for about two years and her business is open from 6 am until 11 pm every day. Jeanne currently employs one person to help her.

Jeanne and her team have requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to increase their businesses by purchasing more drinks and food for sale. With any profits, Jeanne and her team will reinvest in their businesses and save for their family's future.

loans.use: To increase her restaurant by purchasing more drinks and food for sale.

loans.name: Ismail

texts.en:
Ismail is 39 years old and lives in the town of Kijura in the Hoima region of Uganda. He is married and has three children, two of them currently in school. Ismail has a clothes business, which he has had for six years. He also has a second business of selling produce like beans, maize.  

To help expand his business, Ismail has requested a loan of 1000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase clothes for resale. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Ismail hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. In the future, he hopes to get a sewing machine and start making clothes himself.

loans.use: to purchase clothes for resale.

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en:
For the past 20 years Luisa, 46 years old and married, has had a retail shop where she sells a variety of products. She earns approximately PHP 4,000 monthly. Luisa is requesting a loan of Php 11,000 to purchase a variety of products that she can display in her store to attract more customers. She will buy noodles, canned goods, coffee, bread and sugar to sell.

In the future, Luisa hopes that her business will improve so that she can better provide for the needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy noodles, canned goods, coffee, bread and sugar to sell.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is 22 years old and single. He has been running his butchery business for six months. His monthly income is KES 6,000, which he uses in his business.

He has been loaned KES 10,000 by KADET Ltd. This is his first loan from KADET. He intends to use his loan to purchase more meat for sale in his butchery.

He plans to use the profit from his business to expand and also to add more stock. In the future, he hopes to open up another butchery.

loans.use: To purchase more meat for sale in his butchery.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is 36 years old and lives in the town of Kijura in the Hoima region of Uganda. He is married and has four children, all of them currently in school. Robert has a spare parts shop, which he has had for three years.         

To help expand his business, Robert has requested a loan of 1000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase spares. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Robert hopes to generate greater profits and pays school fees for his family. In the future, Robert hopes to own a factory that makes motorcycles.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is 51 years old and married to Abel. 

She has been operating her tailoring business for 12 years. She earns a monthly income of about KES 30,000, which she uses to take care of her business and family.

She has been loaned KES 20,000 by KADET Ltd. She intends to use her loan to purchase materials and clothes for sale.

She plans to use the profit from her business to open another tailoring shop within her residential area to serve her customers better.

In the future, she hopes to have a tailoring school.

loans.use: to purchase materials and clothes for sale.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
She is 38 years old and married to a farmer. She has three children and one goes to school.

She is currently in the business of selling milk. She purchases milk and sells it in the market.

Now she is requesting a loan to purchase more milk to get more profit. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to make her own house.

loans.use: to purchase more milk to sell.

loans.name: Ramish

texts.en:
Ramish is a very serious man. He is the father of two children and has the responsibility of supporting his family and providing them with everything that they need. 

He can manage tough jobs like raising sheep. He started the business in 2008. He usually purchases lambs for a low price, raises them and sells them in the local central bazaar for a profit. His monthly income is 250 USD.  

His greatest goal nowadays is to improve his economic situation and provide a better way of life for his family. It is for this reason that Ramish applied for an 800 AZN loan to purchase more sheep for breeding.

loans.use: to purchase eight sheep and fodder.

loans.name: Maryline

texts.en:
Maryline is 22 years old and lives in Congo Town. She is single and has two children ages 2 and 5. They both live with her grandmother and are attending school.

For the past two years, Maryline has been selling frozen chicken and ribs. She started this business with 2,000 LRD, which was given to her by her mother. She is requesting a loan to purchase a carton of frozen chicken and ribs for her business. 

She faces a challenge in that sometimes her customers use credit and refuse to pay.

She hopes to go back to school and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase a carton of frozen chicken and ribs for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more food items to sell.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 37 years old and married. He has two children who go to school.  

He sells fish to earn a living. He has been operating the business for nine years.  

Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has become more aggressive in his business because he has to deal with the high competition in his business location. Faulu Kenya has trained him in good customer care. 

He hopes to move to a bigger business premise and employ people. He has requested 10,000 KES to buy fish and a stand for displaying fish.

loans.use: To buy fish and a stand for displaying fish.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase rice, oil, fish and spices for her business.

loans.name: Yasin

texts.en:
Yasin is 28 years old and lives in the town of Kijura in the Hoima region of Uganda. He is single and has one child not yet in school. Yasin has a business of a stationary shop that sells exercise books and the use of a printing machine, which he has had for two years. He also has a second business of a small shop that sells produce like maize.  

To help expand his business, Yasin has requested a loan of 2000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more printing paper, and exercise books for sale. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Yasin hopes to generate greater profits and improve his standard of living. In the future, Yasin hopes to own a factory that makes printing paper.

loans.use: to purchase more printing paper and exercise books to sell.

loans.name: Selina

texts.en:
She is 30 years old and married. She has four children and her children go to school.

She has four cows. Her main income is milk sales.

She is requesting a loan for two more cows. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to buy two cows.

loans.name: Tarafat

texts.en:
Tarafat is a 37-year-old farmer who raises fruits trees. She has run her business for ten years. She usually sells crops to the local people or takes them to the central city bazaar. Her monthly profit is 150 USD. 

Tarafat would like to increase her profit and for this purpose she has applied for a 1,500 AZN loan. This will allow her to improve the quality of her land and purchase seeds and fertilizer. 

Tarafat has good client history and thanks everybody who supports her with this loan.

loans.use: To improve the quality of her land and purchase seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Sebastian

texts.en:
Sebastian is 26 years old; He has been operating his business for the past two years. He earns a monthly income of about 30,000 KES (~$340) from his calling card business. 

He has applied for 42,000 KES from KADET LTD. This is his second loan from KADET LTD. He intends to use his loan to purchase calling cards in large quantities, which will enable him to get more profit.

He plans to use the profit from his business to open up a kiosk, which will be his central selling point instead of hawking around. In the future, he hopes to start a taxi business.

loans.use: to purchase calling cards in large quantities.

loans.name: Marie

texts.en:
Marie is 43 years old and lives in Congo town. She is a widow and has seven children, three of whom live at home with her, while the others are by themselves. 

For the past three years she has been operating a small food center where she sells Liberian dishes. She has a lot of customers and she makes a lot of money, which is helping her to look after her children. 

She is requesting a loan to purchase rice oil and other spices for her business. In the future she plans to make her shop a restaurant.

loans.use: to purchase rice oil and other spices for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase newer instruments for hair cutting and shaving.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles, a 39-year-old resident of the town of Masidi in the Hoima region of Uganda, is married and has two children, both of whom are currently in school. For the past three years, Charles has operated a business making saucepans. He also has a small retail shop that sells essential commodities like sugar.

To help expand his business, Charles has requested a loan of 1000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda to purchase iron for making saucepans. With the help of the loan, he hopes to generate greater profits and pay the school fees for his children. In the future, Charles hopes to own a factory that makes saucepans.

loans.use: to purchase iron for making saucepans.

loans.name: Jalal

texts.en:
Jalal is 41 years old. He is married with two children. He sells foodstuffs like macaroni, wheat, buckwheat, cotton seed oil and other products. 

When he started the business three years ago it was only retail sales. Gradually expanding the business, he purchased the goods as a wholesaler and distributed them among the stores. The business became successful and stable and his current monthly profit is about $250.

Jalal requests a 900 AZN loan for purchasing foodstuffs to increase the range of goods for sale.  He already completed his first loan from AqroInvest CU and has a good client history. He thanks all supporting him and promises to pay the loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: to purchase more foodstuffs to increase the range of goods for sale.

loans.name: Clarice

texts.en:
Clarice is 38 years old and married to Thomas. She has been operating her tailoring business for the past eighteen years. She earns a monthly income of about 20,000 KES (~$225) which she uses to take care of her business and family.

She has been loaned 20,000 KES by KADET Ltd. She intends to use her loan to purchase a stock of materials and also clothes for sale.

Clarice plans to use the profit from her business to open another tailoring shop within her residential area to serve her customers better. In the future, she hopes to have a tailoring school to pass her knowledge on to those who need it.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of materials and also clothes for sale.

loans.name: Ma.delsa

texts.en:
Ma.Delsa is 57 years old and a widow with four children.

Ma.Delsa works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 22,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stocks to sell in her sari-sari store.

Ma.Delsa has borrowed and paid 21 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 10 years and also earns an income from a carenderia (restaurant).

Ma.Delsa aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy additional stocks to sell

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann is 31 years old and single with two children. With two children in school, Mary Ann works very hard to provide for them.

Mary Ann runs a business of buying and selling of silver jewelries in the Philippines and requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stocks of silver jewelries to sell.

Mary Ann has been in this business for two years and sells a variety of items such as necklaces, earrings, and rings. 

In the future, Mary Ann would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more stocks of silver jewelries

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane is 35 years old and married with five children. With four children in school, Mary Jane works very hard to provide for them.

Mary Jane runs a business of buying and selling charcoal in the Philippines and requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell.

Mary Jane has been in this business for six years.

In the future, Mary Jane would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy merchandise to increase his assortment of items for sale.

loans.name: Sheilla

texts.en:
Sheilla is a 29-year-old married lady.  She runs a hardware shop to earn a living. She has been in this business for seven years and has employed two people.  

She joined a group in Faulu Kenya so that she could easily access financial resources, and because the members of the group guarantee each others' loans.  She has also grown her business because she has been trained on business management skills.  She hopes to expand her business in the future.  

She has requested 30,000 KES to buy wheels, rings and brushes.

loans.use: to buy wheels, rings and brushes.

loans.name: Ana May

texts.en:
Ana May is 47 years old and married with 1 adult-aged child. She has a retail shop where she sells a variety of products that she can offer in the community. She has had this business for 6 years and she earns approximately 4,000 PHP (~$100) monthly.

Ana May is requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP to purchase additional groceries and soft drinks to sell. She really wants to increase her income but she has insufficient capital. That's why she is asking for financial assistance from the Kiva lenders, and she is hoping that her request will be granted. 

In the future, she hopes that her business will expand so she can save some funds for future use and to raise their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase additional groceries and soft drinks to sell.

loans.name: Nieves

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Nieves works hard to support her family.

She has a food vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from raising pigs.  Nieves is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business. 

Nieves has been sustaining her business activities through her past 12 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to repair and renovate her family home and send her child to college.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy additional food items to increase the variety of goods he sells.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is currently in the business of making local alcohol and is requesting a loan to expand her business. She is 40 years old and married with a husband who is a businessman. She has 5 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to provide for her family.

loans.use: to expand her small business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy beer and soda.

loans.name: Everlyne

texts.en:
Everlyne, a 28-year-old married mother of an eight-year child, has been running her salon business for the past five years. She earns a monthly income of about KES 6,300, some of which she saves and some of which she uses for the business.

Everlyne is requesting her first loan of KES 20,000 from KADET LTD to purchase beauty/cosmetic products and hair extensions for sale and for use in the salon. She plans to use the anticipated profit to save and open her own salon, as she currently works from the house.

loans.use: to purchase beauty/cosmetic products and hair extensions for sale and for use in the salon.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase new tools.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is 26 years old and lives in the town of Kinubi in the Hoima region of Uganda.  He is married and has one child, who isn't currently in school. Ibrahim is involved in a grocery business since one year.         

To help expand his business, Ibrahim has requested a loan of 1000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used for purchasing grocery items for resale. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Ibrahim hopes to generate greater profits and buy food for his family.  In the future, Ibrahim hopes to expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery items for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The purchase of more retail commodities like sugar, rice,salt and beans to resell

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en:
Anecita is 47 years old and married with four grown children. She has a retail shop where she sells a variety of products to the community. Anecita has been in business for six years, and she earns approximately 3,000 PHP monthly.

Anecita is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP to buy rice, canned goods and soft drinks to sell. In the future, Anecita hopes that her business will expand to increase her profits and so provide for the needs of her children.

loans.use: to buy rice, canned goods and soft drinks to sell.

loans.name: Kristine

texts.en:
Kristine is 31 years old, married and blessed with three children, thirteen years, eight years, and nine months old. Her husband, Robert, works for the Kenya army.

Kristine has been selling her seat covers for three years. She earns a monthly income of about 10,500 KES which she uses to take care of her family and apply to her business.

Kristine has applied for a loan, her first from KADET Ltd., of 10,000 KES. She intends to use the loan to purchase more cloth to make seat covers. She plans to use her anticipated profits to expand her business.

In the future Kristine hopes to open her own shop, as presently she works from her house. She would like to see her children reach a higher level of education.

loans.use: to purchase more cloth to make seat covers.

loans.name: Dorcus
